title: Broadcasting Jargon
description: Go behind the scenes of radio and television with this quiz on broadcasting industry terminology.

questions.question: What does 'dead air' mean in broadcasting?
options: An unintended period of silence during a broadcast

questions.question: What is a 'cue' in broadcasting?
options: A waiting line at the studio
A signal to begin an action, such as starting to speak or play a segment

questions.question: What does 'simulcast' mean?
options: Broadcasting the same program simultaneously on multiple platforms or channels

questions.question: What is the 'control room' in a broadcast facility?
options: The room where security monitors the building
The room where equipment is stored
The room where directors and technical staff manage the live broadcast

questions.question: What does 'bumper' refer to in television?
options: A segment that exceeds its time slot
A brief transition element, often with graphics and music, used before and after commercial breaks
A protective cover for camera equipment

questions.question: What is 'B-roll'?
options: The credits that roll at the end
Supplemental footage used to visually support or illustrate what the narrator or speaker is saying
The second camera in a studio

questions.question: What does 'prime time' traditionally refer to?
options: The evening hours when the largest television audience is available, typically 8-11 PM
The time when the best shows premiere

questions.question: What is a 'teleprompter'?
options: A tool for prompting audience applause
A device that displays scrolling text for a presenter to read while looking at the camera

questions.question: What does 'uplink' mean in broadcasting?
options: Transmitting a signal from a ground station up to a satellite

questions.question: What is 'syndication' in broadcasting?
options: The licensing of a program for broadcast by multiple stations or networks
A group of criminals in a TV show

questions.question: What does 'sweeps' refer to in television?
options: Removing old programs from the schedule
Specific periods when audience measurement data is collected to set advertising rates

questions.question: What is a 'sound bite'?
options: A short, memorable excerpt from a longer interview or speech used in a broadcast

questions.question: What does 'chroma key' refer to?
options: A type of camera lens filter
A key used to lock the studio
A technique using a colored background (usually green or blue) that is replaced with another image in post-production

questions.question: What is a 'rundown' in broadcasting?
options: A detailed outline or sequence of segments for a show, listing timing and content

questions.question: What does 'wrap' mean at the end of a broadcast production?
options: The signal that shooting or recording is finished for the day
